entry.content:
This is how you die. On your back, with a broken leg and worms crawling over and into your body.

Well, it's one of many ways you can die. Most of them involve trauma and worms. One will involve something approaching natural causes.

As with life, so with games. You're going to have to do a lot of things right just to stay alive, and even then, a good outcome isn't certain.

The destination is certain, but it's how you get there that counts.

entry.content:
Welp. It's been exactly two months since I added any update to the blog - or even touched the game.

To be fair to myself - or to give myself an excuse - there have been distractions. Mid-December was the run-up to Christmas, we were having an en-suite bathroom done, and then, just after Christmas, I acquired a 3D printer.

Since then, most of my free time has gone into designing, printing and using new things. These include wine racks, lithophane lamps, various useful accesories, and of course, repeating crossbows - which are incredible fun, and if Day of the Worms happens in real life, could be a great advantage against the zombie hordes..

Two months is a long time though, and Day of the Worms has been nagging for my attention at the back of my subconscious.

I've definnitely missed the chance to get the game into February's Steam Next as I had planned.

This morning, I scanned some drawings I made in December, and am incorporating them into the game.

It's not that impressive, and amounted to a broken window and a shard of glass, which will be useful later on.

But it is something, and I'm ready to start work on the next area!

Stay tuned for more updates.

entry.title: Some UI changes
entry.summary: It's difficult to strike the balance between showing enough information when the player needs it, and cluttering up the interface. When the player is wandering around the world, we want the screen to be as clear as possible, to allow the player to choose to…
entry.content:
It's difficult to strike the balance between showing enough information when the player needs it, and cluttering up the interface.

When the player is wandering around the world, we want the screen to be as clear as possible, to allow the player to choose to look at and interact with objects, scenery, and other characters.

To this end, the inventory is hidden when not in use, and only appears when the mouse is very near to the top of the screen. This allows the player to click on objects wherever they are on the y axis.

Likewise, I think having object and hotspot descriptions visible on a simple mouseover will be distracting, especially when the player has already read the description and knows what it is and does.

Everything in the world that has a description can be looked at with the right mouse button. There are no pop-ups, and triggering the description by looking at the object or hotspot has to be a conscious decision. That you can trigger another action is indicated by the cursor showing an eye, hand, or mouth.

Inventory objects are another matter. The player has their inventory open for a reason, and being able to scan quick desciptions is important, and can give clues to gameplay. For instance, is a bucket full of water or empty? Inventory mouseover pops the gActionBar at the bottom to give a quick description of what the object is. Using right-click (usually the Look action) to display text would block the action - requiring two clicks in total, so now, right click does nothing. I figure that up to 12 words is easily enough for the action bar GUI.

The other advantage of this is that I don't need to define functions for each type of click on an inventory item, as everying is dealt with automatically.Â

entry.content:
Almost two weeks after posting that the first area was almost complete, I haveÂ actually completed the first area.

My big mistake was neglecting to consider the implications of DOTW being a point and click adventure with interactive fiction elements.

In practice, this means that that there are multiple paths the character can take, and multiple ways to get there. Sure, most of them end in death, but they all need menus, they all need artwork, and they all need to make sense.

Many of these are just entertaining diversions en route to a predetermined outcome, but they take time to create.

Next step is the outside of the second allotment plot. In earlier iterations, this was a different choice, but I'd like to give the player a brief respite after (unless they were very lucky) figuring out how not to die while repeatedly dying.

I'm pretty pleased with artwork for a few of the area endings.

entry.content:
I previously mentioned that Day of the Worms was originally built as an Interactive Fiction game for Android - don't bother looking for it - I very much doubt it's compatible with any recent Android versions, if, indeed, it's still available.

I also ported it to Twine so that it would play in the browser. If you fancy giving it a go, it's available here. It's also somewhere in the menu.

These are the bones on which the point and click adventure is being built. It will have much of the same (possibly all of the same) text, but with hand drawn images, animations, and of course, it's a point and click.

Fun fact: the background image for the TWINE version is actually a photograph of my old plot on the Ilford Avenue allotments that I ran through GIMP.

I recall that some of the mechanics didn't quite work, but can't remember what exactly.

entry.content:
I'm happy with the first scene so far. The artwork looks decent (for an unspecified value of decent), and things do what they're supposed to do.

So far, that isn't much. The gardener needs to get into his shed, but doesn't have his keys.

He needs to take the ladder, put it against the apple tree, and climb it to get the keys from a bird box. It's not an especially difficult puzzle.

Figuring out how to get him to climb the ladder took the better part of a day on its own. (eventual solution: create a horizontal pixel-wide gap in the walkable area, walk to top edge of lower area, move character across the gap, create the illusion of walking up the ladder using baseline to keep it between the character and the tree, then do it backwards).

Once he has the key, he can enter the shed. The interior currently looks like this:

Which is a bit pants.

I'm going to spend the next few days drawing the inside of an allotment shed, along with the typical stuff you'd fiind in there - gas bottles, cups, tools, string, pots, and so on. You'd never seen a hoarder until you've met an allotment gardener. Nothing goes to waste. On the other hand, I don't want the playable area to be too cluttered.

I've also reskinned the GUI, givng the game an appropriate hand-drawn inventory and themeatically appropriate volume and speed sliders:

The buttons have mouseover images, and each of those buttons leads to sub menus that also have buttons. It took an absolute age to do.

I am actually really pleased with the inventory and various buttons. Again, they have mouseover images, and the spray bottles are left and right controls to go through the inventory.

entry.title: It walks! It talks!
entry.summary: Yet another switcharoo, and I've settled on AGS for the game engine. There are several reasons for this: It's pretty easy to get the character to walk behind objects, make areas clickable, and it just seems... straightforward. Sticking this area together from my drawings, and…
entry.content:
Yet another switcharoo, and I've settled on AGS for the game engine. There are several reasons for this:

  1. The documentation is exhaustive, with many people compiling their own manuals, as well as video tutorials of varying quality.
  2. It comes with some sensible demo modes and prebuilt mockups, allowing me to easily choose an interface type.
  3. There's already an inventory system as well as save/load functionality.
  4. Anything else would probably be overkill.

It's pretty easy to get the character to walk behind objects, make areas clickable, and it just seems... straightforward.

Sticking this area together from my drawings, and making it actuallyÂ work took a couple of hours. OK, you can't interact with anything beyond walking over to it and commenting, yet, but I'm pretty pleased.

Animating the main character (The Gardener) took an additional few hours in Gimp.

entry.summary: After playing some awesome Wadjeteye games, I wanted to create DOTW with a pixelart style, but after some experimentation, I've determined that this is just something I'm not very good at. Instead, I've gone back to something I know and love - doodling. I'm using…
entry.content:
After playing some awesome Wadjeteye games, I wanted to create DOTW with a pixelart style, but after some experimentation, I've determined that this is just something I'm not very good at.

Instead, I've gone back to something I know and love - doodling. I'm using a 0.4mm black fineliner to create drawings in a style I can do consistently.

I know I can do this because throughout my secondary school days, I would spend entire lessons with a biro or fountain pen, outlining and filling in A4 pages. It's a very particular technique, and I enjoy it.

It would be nice to have some of my notepads and exercise books from back in the day, but they are unfortunately decades in the past.

This means DOTW will probably end up being monochrome or two-tone - I'm quite happy with this, but I'm also thinking about experimenting with watercolour pens. I don't know yet.
